turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Get back!!

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: The generator!

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Screw the generator!!

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Got Sanchez... World War Three wouldn't mess with this fucker... Can go through walls... And it's like all over the place...

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Calm down and get in your position.

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Position, my ass...

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Maybe it ain't coming.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Then we go after him.

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Bet the last place you ever go.

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: You jerking off or just pissed?

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: We got any more of those electronic chess things down in supply?

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: Get your gear on.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: What for?

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: Magnesium of some type... or some kind of strange alloy.  And those poor dumb bastards had to go and blow the hell out of it.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: So what do you make of it?

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: You know damn well what we both make of it.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: No chance it could have been some new kind of test craft?

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: Somebody else sure as hell thought so.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Who else could have used that key?

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: We should sleep in shifts.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Right.  Half of us awake at all times.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: What's happened?!

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: MacReady, that you?

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Yeah!

turns.speaker: NORRIS
turns.text: It's the generator I think!  No power.

turns.speaker: MACREADY
turns.text: Well, let's get down there.

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: ... Made sure I got ahead of him on the towline on the way back... cut him loose.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: MacReady...?

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: He's one of them.

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: When do you think it got to him?

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: You hear that?

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: Hear what?

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: It's got into the pub!  It's turned on the stereo!

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: What?!

turns.speaker: NAULS
turns.text: It's in between us and them!!  How we going to get back?!

turns.speaker: SANCHEZ
turns.text: Can't hear you.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: It must have been hard, leaving your work.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: The journey is part of my work.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: Now how did you get hurt?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I had an accident.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I figured that.  What kind of accident?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: What do you do on the towers?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: On the towers?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I'm training to be a high climber.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Ah... no.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: Don't tell me you're a mud carrier.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: 'Fraid so.  Just a regular old... mud carrier.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... Thousands and thousands of people.  And sometimes we live in great buildings that reach up five or ten stories.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: And everyone looks like us?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Exactly like you.  Well, maybe not as healthy.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: She didn't want me to be a climber. She wanted me to be a planner like her.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm so sorry, Kalen.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How can they just go back to work as if nothing happened?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: What else can they do?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Kalen... Do you have any idea where they take them?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: We're not supposed to think about it.  But I dream about it sometimes...

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: There's a place that might help... we could try going there.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Where?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: The Hall of Books.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You have books?!  Kalen, you've got to take me there.  There might be history.  Records.  Something to help us find where the Morlocks took --

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I shouldn't have mentioned it.  We can't go there.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: No one ever comes here.  My mother told me stories about it late at night.  They tell all the children.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What kind of stories?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: About the voice in the darkness. About the ghosts...

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: I had a friend who came here once. Sort of a dare.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What happened?

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: He came back screaming... He never talked about it after that.  I don't think he even got this far.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I think we should go on by ourselves.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Please, just listen to me... Your mother would be very cross with me if you got hurt.  I'll find her.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: But you're only a mud carrier.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'll be all right... You go back to the village and light the fire.  So we can find our way home.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... Well, you wanted to see it.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: This is it?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Around here.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.  Just about here.

turns.speaker: KALEN
turns.text: But there's nothing here.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Right up your alley, I would think. You are from the past, yes?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How did you know?!

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I can smell carcinogens and industrial pollutants on your skin that have not been known here for --  -- 800,000 years perhaps.  Don't keep me in suspense.  What year?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I must say, you look remarkably good.  You don't want a book then?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What are you?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I'm the librarian.  I've always been the librarian.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know you -- you're an automaton of some sort that --

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: An "automaton"?!  Please!  I'm a biomechanical organism.  Well, what's left of one.  What's left of all of them, actually.  I am the last...  ... And "these fragments I have shored against my ruins."  T.S. Eliot.  You wouldn't know him yet but you'll just love him, he's divine, if a little dour.  Very shy though... hiding over here...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Sir... have you a name?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I am called Vox...  ... Now you are Eloi.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Please, we need your help.  The Morlocks have taken --

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Morlocks --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You know of them?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Who doesn't know the Morlocks?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Do you know where they live?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Oh yes... They found our knowledge useful for a time.  They used us much as your people did.  Then they decided they had learned enough so they tore us up for spare parts.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: But you escaped.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I was lucky.  The others weren't.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How have you survived so long?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Regenerating fission reactor, you wouldn't understand.  It's power is well beyond your neanderthal cranial capacity.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Can you show us where they live?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: We need your help.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Why should I help you?  You primates -- you great, lumbering, hairy animals, drenched in blood from the moment of your hideous conception -- what have you ever used knowledge for but destruction and bloodshed!  A little bit of learning and you lay waste to the world!  You're no better than the Morlocks!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Because you'll never die.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Excuse me?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You'll live like this forever. Alone.  You were meant to help.  To be with people.  Not like this.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: So, Relic, you want to open Pandora's box, do you?  See all the mysteries exposed?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: And if the truth is so horrible that it will haunt your dreams for all time?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm used to that.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: When was his mother taken?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Last night.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Send him away.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Send him home.  You don't want him to see it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Kalen... hold on a minute.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My God... I saw this.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: It frightens you.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes...

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: It was meant to.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: So, do we go on?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Aren't you a plucky little -- ?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh, shut up.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: It's what they want you to see.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This is the way in?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Yes... Are you sure you want to do this?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes.  But you've done enough. Thank you for your help... I hope someday people read your books again.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: In for a penny, in for a pound.  Do you know that saying?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Yes... Thank you.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Machines?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Do you know which way?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Vox?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: This way.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What's it all for?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: The air... the power.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why did they built it?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: The Morlocks didn't build this.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Alexander... Listen to me, it was wrong to bring you.  You're not going to find what you're looking for.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What do you mean?

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Trust me... You don't want to see any more.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: They raise them like cattle... Feed them until they're ready and then hunt them.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: How are your dreams now?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This has to end.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: End...?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This has to end.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Vox --

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Imagine that... seems that little devil got my power relays...

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Takes a licking but keeps on ticking...  ... For a while anyway.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What can I do?  Tell me what to do.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Nothing to do, I'm afraid.  I'm just a librarian after all.  Wasn't exactly made for all this swashbuckling.  Very Byronic end, though.  I appreciate that.  Do you know Byron?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Vox...

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I'm babbling.  Good to have someone to talk to for a change... But you need to go.  Take her out of here...  ... I don't have long.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I won't leave you like this.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Go back to the light.  You weren't made for this.  I was... I was made for this moment.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I don't understand.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I'm going to end it, Alexander.  As we discussed...

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: Now get out of my sight, you hideous primate.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'll never forget this.

turns.speaker: VOX
turns.text: I should hope not...  ... Alexander... Make them read my books.  Tell them who they are. Who they could be.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I will...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: What's your name?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Alexander.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Well, Alexander, as a fellow scientist I know you have a thousand questions --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You came underground when the world was ending above.  And you evolved. Some into the Morlocks and others --

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: No, we created the Morlocks.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Created?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: You wouldn't understand.  We genetically engineered the Morlock class to serve our needs.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: As slaves.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: To work the machines and build the tunnels.  You can't imagine what it was like when it all started.  We survived for millennia, scraping the lichen and microscopic organisms from the rock with our teeth and digging for water with our nails.  Endlessly.  For generations.  And we... became.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: And centuries later when we tried to emerge into the sun again, we couldn't.  Our adaptation was too successful.  We survived... we endured... for this.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How do you control the Morlocks?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: We make them see what we wish.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: As our bodies atrophied our minds... compensated.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: And what of the Eloi?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: They survived above.  Became what they are.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No... they didn't survive only to be your food.  You did that.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: I'm afraid your indignation is lost here.  I have no more "human" response to the Eloi then you would have to a carrot.  It's just how we live now.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: But this is barbaric!  Have you completely lost all sense of --

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: And who are you, Alexander?  Who are you to question thousands of years of evolution?  This is the world now.  I am fact.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It can't all be like this...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Go back to where you came from.  Or die here.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why would you let me go back?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Because the past is immutable. Frozen.  Dead... And you are the past.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Say I just come back again?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Alexander, yours is a world of brocade and velvet, not tooth and claw.  Why would you come back to this?  To save a few cattle?  No.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I could tell them.  Warm them of what's to come.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: We have lost the capacity to reproduce.  But the species must continue.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: So you take their best...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: When a creature shows too much independent thought we remove them from the gene pool.  We're breeding them for submission.  Soon they will be fully domesticated.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You took her because she helped me.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Yes.  Initiative and daring are not desirable traits in the Eloi.  But you should be happy for her.  She won't remember the creature she was.  She will... become.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: She won't remember you.  None of them will.  You will be forgotten. That is how history works.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: A man can change his history.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: After all you've seen... after man's entire journey... you still believe that?

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Now will you go?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: If I can only find the right door... the lady or the tiger...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: It's always the tiger for you, Alexander, haven't you learned that by now?...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: That was a foolish thing to do.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm a foolish man.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: I could have a hundred Morlocks here in thirty seconds.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Does this prove something to you? Have you made some great stand of which I'm unaware?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm tired of running.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: Oh, you won't be running for long...

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: But you've earned a reward for your valor.  I think you should become. You'll like it here.  Once you get used to the darkness.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I don't think that's going to happen.

turns.speaker: OVERLORD
turns.text: And why not?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Because...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It's spectacular...

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: Thanks.  Old Nell's my girl all right.  Al least when she decides to move, stubborn beast.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I've only read about them -- and the new internals.

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: Now that's what I call plain crazy -- internal combustion is just too dangerous, all those little explosions, never catch on.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: How do you keep the water temperature stable?

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: There's a cantilevered gasket on the --

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: God -- could have killed me -- bad girl, Nell!  How did you know to do that?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I just love mechanical things.

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: Well, much obliged -- I'm always forgetting the confounded brake -- say, if you wait until I get her up and running I'll give you a perambulation.  Tell you all about her.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Ahhh... I'm afraid I've got a prior commitment.

turns.speaker: MOTORIST
turns.text: Next time then.  We perambulate here most every night.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You have my word...  ... She's just a beauty.

turns.speaker: VOX KIOSK
turns.text: May I help you?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I -- what are you?!

turns.speaker: VOX KIOSK
turns.text: I am the Fifth Avenue Public Library informational kiosk.  VOX registration NY-114.  May I help you?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What's happening to the moon?!

turns.speaker: VOX KIOSK
turns.text: The 2005 terraforming demolitions for the lunar excavations sent the moon into a diminishing retrograde orbit resulting in global gravitational fluctuations, increased seismic activity and tidal anomalies.  Can I tell you more?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No -- wait -- the moon's falling out of orbit -- that's not possible!

turns.speaker: VOX KIOSK
turns.text: Well, considering it is, in fact, happening, I would assume it's possible.  The retrograde orbit began in 2005 when the demolitions for the lunar colonies --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Why is it -- breaking up?

turns.speaker: VOX KIOSK
turns.text: I was getting to that... The moon has reached the gravitational Roche Limit, 7,300 miles above the surface of the Earth.  This has created pressure on the lunar stratum beyond gravitational tolerances.  It might be helpful to know that the nearest public evacuation shelters can be found at Grand Central Station, Madison Square Garden --

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You're late.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Got here as soon as I could.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Dance with me...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You know I can't.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Trust me...

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You promised me flowers.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You promised me flowers tonight, don't you even remember?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Sorry... I was distracted.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Well there's something new.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I need to... um... talk to you.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Talk away, Professor.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Not here... alone.  May we? Please?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: ... Orion's belt, pointing to the earth.  You see it over the rocks there?  Sailors consider that an omen of good fortune; the hunter watching over them on their travels... Are you listening to me, Alex?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: What?  Yes -- Orion -- good fortune -- sailors.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: All right, what is it now?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Emma, you know I have great... admiration for you.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Admiration?  My my.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I mean... well... affection.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You're getting warmer.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh dammit, I love you!  I can't eat, I can't sleep, I can't think, all I do is moon over you and -- hum, apparently.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: And what do you propose, Professor? Shall we hold a seminar to study the problem?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You know, the moment is rather dying here.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Hold on... I know I have it...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I know it's not a diamond but --

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: A moonstone.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Your birth stone.  I thought --

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You're late.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Got here as soon as I could.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Dance with me...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You know I can't.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Trust me...

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Alex, what is it?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Holding you... again.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Darling.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I need... to talk to you.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: All right...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Not here... alone.  Please.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Let's walk through the park...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No... let's walk through the city.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: All right...

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Alex, what is it?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Nothing -- let's just get out of the park.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Alex...?!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Shhh.  Let's just hurry on here. We don't have to talk, all right?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Why do we have to race for heaven's sake?!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I want to get into the light, that's all.  Please...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: My God...

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Alex, it's just the zoo.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: You're so pale... I hope you're not coming down with something.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: No, I'm fine.  I'm...  ... wonderful.  Just walking down the street with you again.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: We took a walk three days ago.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Not like this.  Never like this. Emma, I swear to you -- if I've learned one thing, it's that moments like this are rare.  And I will thank God for them every moment of every day.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: They are rare...  ... Orion's belt, pointing to the earth --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: The sailor's omen of good fortune. The hunter watching over him on his travels.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: So it's astronomy now, is it?

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Heavens, look at that now!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I've seen it.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Now I know you're ill -- passing up the chance to explore some new gadget.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: It's only a machine.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Alex... people are staring.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Let them.

turns.speaker: EMMA
turns.text: Let them.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I have something for you...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... The point is I know it will work once the, um, numbers and such are in order.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Do you know you were humming?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I was not.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Somewhere around "D+2xy something something."

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Damned if I can keep her out of my equations.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Tonight's the night?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: God, and I'm running late --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: ... One day he'll be discovered by some future archeologists and they won't know what to make of him. The thick brow, so lacking in imagination.  The dim little eyes, devoid of curiosity.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: You know generally teachers are supposed to teach real equations that add up to real numbers.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Where's the challenge in that?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Alex, this is your first year as an associate professor.  You might want to play things a little more conservatively.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You sound like my father...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Look at them, Philby, all alike, everyone in an identical bowler hat.  Do you want your students to turn out like them?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I want my students to emerge with theoretical and practical knowledge.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I don't.  I want them to run along this street and knock off every bowler they see.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: You may not like it, but this is the world we live in, Alex.  Little grey men with little grey hats.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: But shouldn't it be better? Shouldn't we be teaching our students to imagine a world beyond all this?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: In the future, we'll be better.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Nothing.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Emma actually likes chalk dust -- says it smells like me.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: How romantic...

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: The most able inventor I know and you can't tie a simple four-in- hand.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That's how I knew we were destined to be together.  When I met her parents for the first time I came right from class and I was covered in chalk.  They sniffed and snorted, but she just smiled.  At that moment -- I just knew.  How did you know with Molly?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: She made the best Shepherd's pie I ever tasted.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Do you have a romantic bone in your body?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: No, I'm all bowler hat, remember?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Alex, really... good luck tonight. She's a fine girl, and she's done wonderful things for you.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: She's gotten into your equations.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: All these clocks -- how can you constantly be running late?!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Perseverance.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I've been working.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I came by the house every day after the funeral.  And then every week. Then every other month.  Then I stopped coming.  Did you even notice?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'm sorry, David.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: It hurt me, Alex.  Very much.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Then why are you here?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: It's my Jamie's birthday today. Your godson.  He's nine years old. At his party he asked me if Uncle Alex was coming.  I told him no. Then he asked me if you didn't like him anymore.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: For God's Sake, David --

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: There are some things I need to say to you.  You may not like hearing them, but I don't know if I'll ever get another chance --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You care for me.  And you're concerned.  And I have to start living my life again.  I hear it from Mrs. Watchit every day.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: But you won't listen.  You won't see me, you won't see anyone.  What would you like me to tell Jamie? That Uncle Alex is busy?  That Uncle Alex is hiding up there in his laboratory --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Hiding?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: You know that's what it is.  Mrs. Watchit tells me you're here at all hours -- day and night --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That's because I'm working.  You remember that?  You used to care about your work.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I care more about my life.  And yours.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: What happened to Emma will never go away.  It's part of you now and it always will be.  But you have to learn to live with it...

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I live with it every minute of every day.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I know that --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You don't know that.  You couldn't possibly.  If I'd only done this, or that, if I'd arrived ten minutes earlier, or later.  If we'd taken a different path or I hadn't fought the man for the ring.  You have no idea what it is to relive every moment of that night -- consider every action you made -- and every one of them wrong.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: It wasn't your fault, Alex.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Wasn't it?... I have a dream almost every night now.  The Lady and the Tiger, you remember that story?  In the dream I'm alone in a huge chamber with a thousand doors. Behind every door, save one, is a tiger.  I have to make the decision.  Which door conceals Emma?  And I just stand there... looking at the doors...

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Do you find her?

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Alex, nothing will ever change what happened, but --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That's where you're wrong.  I will change it.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: David... I appreciate your concern, I do.  But I ask you to have faith in me.  Just for a little while longer.  I'm working on something now.  Something... extraordinary.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: What is it?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You wouldn't believe me.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I would.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I'll tell you what... come by for dinner in a week and I'll show you.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Why don't you come to our house instead?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I can't do that --

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: When's the last time you were outside this house --  -- or this room?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I can't leave when I'm so close.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: There are trains leaving Grand Central every then minutes.  A dozen liners leaving the harbor. Get on one of them.  Go to Singapore, Scotland, Manchuria, anywhere, just away from here --

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: That's absurd --

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: You're dying here.  Don't you see that?!

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: You won't say that in a week.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I pray to God that in a week you're not here.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: All right.  I'll come for dinner. And in the meantime... you'll think about what we discussed?

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: In a week... we will never have had this conversation.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Good night, David.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: Good night, Alex.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: And this would be my study.  There was an elm tree outside the window then.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: I'm glad.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: This... was my home.

turns.speaker: PHILBY
turns.text: His home.

turns.speaker: THIN MAN
turns.text: Couldn't help but overhearing.  Two fine young people starting out on the road of life.  I wish you the very best.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Thank you...

turns.speaker: THIN MAN
turns.text: I hope it's a happy journey for you both -- and much as I hate to do this, moved as I am by your protestations of love, I'll be needing your money now.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: Sir...?

turns.speaker: THIN MAN
turns.text: And your jewelry too.  I guess we could consider this your first little bump on the road to married bliss.

turns.speaker: ALEXANDER
turns.text: I don't understand.
